skill.name: managing-docs
skill.description: Expert at organizing and managing documentation structure across projects. Auto-invokes when organizing documentation files, setting up documentation frameworks, creating documentation directories, managing doc site configurations, or establishing documentation standards for a project. Provides guidance on documentation architecture and tooling.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill containing only guidance patterns. All static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. Directory tree diagrams were misidentified as shell commands. Documentation tool names were misidentified as cryptographic algorithms. The skill has no executable code, no network calls, no file operations beyond standard Read/Write/Edit/Glob/Grep/Bash tool capabilities.

content.value_statement: Projects often lack clear documentation structure, making it hard for users and contributors to find information. This skill provides proven architecture patterns, tool setup guides, and standards for organizing documentation at any scale.
actual_capabilities: Suggest documentation directory structures for projects of any size
Provide setup configuration for MkDocs, Docusaurus, Sphinx, and TypeDoc
Define documentation standards including file naming and special files
Create GitHub Actions workflows for automatic documentation deployment
Explain four documentation types: reference, conceptual, procedural, and tutorial
Offer migration strategies for consolidating or restructuring existing docs
limitations: Does not generate actual documentation content or write files directly
Does not execute shell commands or install software
Does not integrate with external documentation services beyond providing config
Does not validate existing documentation or check for completeness

prompt_templates.title: New project setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting documentation for a new project
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up documentation structure for my new [language/framework] project. Include directory layout, recommended files, and configuration for [MkDocs/Docusaurus/Sphinx/TypeDoc].

prompt_templates.title: Restructure docs
prompt_templates.prompt: My project documentation is disorganized. Audit the current structure in [path] and suggest a reorganized layout based on the [simple/standard/large/monorepo] pattern.

prompt_templates.title: Tool configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure [MkDocs/Docusaurus] for my project. I need navigation for [sections], search functionality, and [any specific theme/feature requirements].

prompt_templates.title: Multi-component docs
prompt_templates.scenario: Documenting a complex project with multiple components
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a documentation structure for a monorepo with [number] packages. Each package has [types of components]. Include shared docs strategy and cross-referencing approach.

output_examples.input: Set up documentation structure for my Python project using MkDocs
output: Recommended structure: standard project with docs/ directory
Required files: README.md, CONTRIBUTING.md, CHANGELOG.md, LICENSE
MkDocs plugins: search, autorefs for cross-references
Navigation: Getting Started â†’ Guides â†’ API Reference â†’ Contributing
Theme: material with tabs and section navigation
GitHub Actions workflow included for automatic deployment

output_examples.input: How should I organize docs for my JavaScript monorepo with 5 packages
output: Root docs: architecture overview, package list, cross-package guides
Per-package docs: README, API reference, package-specific guides
Shared content: contributing guide, style guide, troubleshooting
Navigation strategy: root index linking to each package section
Cross-referencing: use MkDocs autorefs or Docusaurus sidebars

best_practices: Start with reader needs: organize documentation by how users search for information, not by internal code structure
Keep documentation files focused: one topic per file with clear, descriptive filenames using lowercase hyphens
Link related content: create a web of cross-references between conceptual guides, tutorials, and API reference docs
anti_patterns: Putting all documentation in a single file instead of breaking it into focused, navigable sections
Including code examples that are not tested or maintained alongside the actual codebase
Creating deeply nested folder structures that make it harder to find information

faq.question: What tools does this skill support?
faq.answer: MkDocs, Docusaurus, Sphinx, and TypeDoc with full configuration examples for each.

faq.question: How big should my docs directory be?
faq.answer: Use simple pattern for small projects, standard for medium, full site for large projects. Scale as project grows.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with CI/CD?
faq.answer: Yes, provides GitHub Actions examples for automatic deployment to GitHub Pages on push.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This is a prompt-only skill. It provides guidance without accessing or storing any project data.

faq.question: Why is my documentation hard to navigate?
faq.answer: Common issues: too many levels of nesting, unclear filenames, missing navigation structure, or no index file.

faq.question: How is this different from writing docs?
faq.answer: This skill handles structure and organization. Use with writing-docs skill for content creation.
